claim: Many people think that Mozart composed Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star, but no recorded composer exists for this tune.

supporting.text: The melody of 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' predates Mozart and is derived from the French folk song 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman'.

attacks.text: The melody of 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' predates Mozart and is derived from the French folk song 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman'.
Mozart did compose a set of variations on 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman', which includes the melody of 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star', making him indirectly associated with the tune.
The variations composed by Mozart are distinct from the original folk melody, and his work does not constitute authorship of the tune itself.
Mozart's variations popularized the melody in classical music, leading to the common misconception that he composed the original tune.

supporting.text: Mozart composed variations on the melody of 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman', which is the same tune as 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star', but he did not create the original melody.

attacks.text: Mozart composed variations on the melody of 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman', which is the same tune as 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star', but he did not create the original melody.
The variations Mozart composed are often mistakenly attributed as the original melody, leading to the misconception that he wrote 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star'.
The widespread association of Mozart with the tune is due to the popularity and recognizability of his variations, overshadowing the original melody's anonymous origins.
The original melody of 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman' predates Mozart and was already a well-known French folk song, making it impossible for him to have composed it.
Historical records of folk songs like 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman' are often incomplete, but Mozart's authorship of the original melody is definitively ruled out by its earlier existence.

supporting.text: Historical musicology records show that 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' is based on a traditional folk tune with no single attributed composer.

attacks.text: Historical musicology records show that 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' is based on a traditional folk tune with no single attributed composer.
Mozart composed variations on the tune, which may have led to the misconception that he composed the original melody.
The variations Mozart composed are distinct from the original folk tune, and his authorship of the variations does not imply authorship of the original melody.
Some folk tunes have been traced to specific composers, so it is possible that the original composer of 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' was simply lost to history.
The lack of any historical record attributing the tune to a specific composer strongly suggests it was a collective folk creation rather than a lost individual work.

supporting.text: The lyrics of 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' were written by Jane Taylor in 1806, long after Mozart's death, further indicating he did not compose the tune.

attacks.text: The lyrics of 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' were written by Jane Taylor in 1806, long after Mozart's death, further indicating he did not compose the tune.
Mozart composed variations on the melody of 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' (Ah! vous dirai-je, maman), which may have led to the misconception that he composed the original tune.
The melody predates Mozart's variations and was already a popular French folk song, making it clear he did not compose the original tune.

supporting.text: Mozart's 'Twelve Variations on 'Ah vous dirai-je, Maman'' (K. 265/300e) is a well-documented work, but it is a set of variations on an existing melody, not the original composition.

attacks.text: Mozart's 'Twelve Variations on 'Ah vous dirai-je, Maman'' (K. 265/300e) is a well-documented work, but it is a set of variations on an existing melody, not the original composition.
The melody of 'Ah vous dirai-je, Maman' predates Mozart, but its origin is unclear, making it plausible that Mozart could have been involved in its popularization.
Historical records show 'Ah vous dirai-je, Maman' was already a well-known French folk song before Mozart's variations, with no evidence linking him to its creation.
Mozart's variations are so iconic that they overshadow the original melody, leading to the common misconception that he composed it.
Misattribution of folk tunes to famous composers is a widespread phenomenon, but it doesn't change the factual record of authorship.
